Colin, thanks for bringing up the DARPA Grand Challenge.  I completely
agree this is an area where neuroevolution and NEAT are well-suited. 
I hope to get involved in this eventually.  I also agree with Mitchell
that it's going to be about obstacle avoidance in pursuit of a goal,
but that's something we've already seen work well with NEAT in some of
our current research.  We've been training robots in real-time to go
around obstacles with good success.

However, there is no doubt this is an enormously expensive
undertaking.  Rather than the learning aspect being the hard part, I
think the hard part will be simulating the sensor and motor
configuration of the actual robot.  Once that simulation is set up,
NEAT will learn in a fairly straightforward manner.  But setting it up
means really purchasing some major industrial rover equipment, which
is thousands of dollars or maybe tens or even hundreds of thousands! 
Then we'd have to drive it around in the real world and take readings
and get a sense of what it sees, and then go back to the simulator.  

We'd also have to build interfaces between the actual sensors of the
robot and the sensors of the NN, since one convention may not be
suitable to the other.  Same with motor outputs and actual motors.  
We'd try to make the simulation->real-world matchup work both ways:
make the simulator look like the real world but *also* make the
real-world look like the simulator from the standpoint of the NN, to
the extent its possible. In other words, a major real-world sensor
preprocessing problem, requiring expertise outside of NN's or NEAT.  

I think it's all doable though, and I hope someday I can get NEAT
involved in this challenge or something like it.  It would require
major funding, though.

ken
